November 2, 2003: Fiction
BLOW FLY, by Patricia Cornwell. (Putnam, $26.95.) No longer the chief medical
examiner of Virginia, Kay Scarpetta tries to unravel a conspiracy involving the
Wolfman, a killer she helped put away years earlier.
THE FIVE PEOPLE YOU MEET IN HEAVEN, by Mitch Albom. (Hyperion, $19.95.)
An old man who died while trying to rescue a little girl from danger discovers that
all will be explained to him in the afterlife.
THE DA VINCI CODE, by Dan Brown. (Doubleday, $24.95.) The murder of a
curator at the Louvre leads to a trail of clues found in the work of Leonardo and to
the discovery of a centuries-old secret society.
SPLIT SECOND, by David Baldacci. (Warner, $26.95.) Two discredited Secret
Service agents become embroiled in political intrigue and murder cases.
BLEACHERS, by John Grisham. (Doubleday, $19.95.) A former star quarterback
returns to his Southern hometown after he learns that his high school coach, a
local legend, has a terminal illness.
THE WEDDING, by Nicholas Sparks. (Warner, $23.95.) A man tries to regain his
wife's love; a sequel to "The Notebook."
HELLO, DARKNESS, by Sandra Brown. (Simon & Schuster, $25.95.) The host of
a late-night radio show in Austin, Tex., finds herself the target of a killer.
CAPITAL CRIMES, by Stuart Woods. (Putnam, $25.95.) President Will Lee and
his wife, the director of central intelligence, search for an assassin who has been
hunting down prominent politicians.
BALANCE OF POWER, by Richard North Patterson. (Ballantine, $27.95.) The
president of the United States sets out to eliminate gun violence and to destroy
lobbyists known as the Sons of the Second Amendment.
THE PLEASURE OF MY COMPANY, by Steve Martin. (Hyperion, $19.95.) A
coming-of-middle-age story about an eccentric named Daniel Pecan Cambridge.
LAST CAR TO ELYSIAN FIELDS, by James Lee Burke. (Simon & Schuster,
$24.95.) Dave Robicheaux returns to New Orleans when the life of an old friend, a
Roman Catholic priest, is threatened.
THE NAMESAKE, by Jhumpa Lahiri. (Houghton Mifflin, $24.) Tracing the fortunes
of a Bengali-American, Gogol Ganguli, whose parents settled in Cambridge,
Mass., after immigrating from Calcutta.
THE TEETH OF THE TIGER, by Tom Clancy. (Putnam, $27.95.) The son of
President Jack Ryan embarks on a career as a counterterrorist agent.
November 2, 2003
Non-Fiction
DUDE, WHERE'S MY COUNTRY? by Michael Moore. (Warner, $24.95.) The
author of "Stupid White Men" calls for "regime change" in Washington.
LIES (AND THE LYING LIARS WHO TELL THEM), by Al Franken. (Dutton,
$24.95.) A satirical critique of the rhetoric of right-wing pundits and politicians.
WHO'S LOOKING OUT FOR YOU? by Bill O'Reilly. (Broadway, $24.95.) The host
of "The O'Reilly Factor" attacks those individuals and institutions that he believes
have let down the American people.
EVERY SECOND COUNTS, by Lance Armstrong with Sally Jenkins. (Broadway,
$24.95.) The second memoir by the five-time winner of the Tour de France.
FLYBOYS, by James Bradley. (Little, Brown, $25.95.) An account of eight
American airmen who were shot down and captured by the Japanese in World
War II.
BUSHWHACKED, by Molly Ivins and Lou Dubose. (Random House, $24.95.) Two
Texas journalists offer up an indictment of the Bush administration.
THE GREAT UNRAVELING, by Paul Krugman. (Norton, $25.95.) A volume of
essays, most from The New York Times, that are "mainly about economic
disappointment, bad leadership and the lies of the powerful."
MADAM SECRETARY, by Madeleine Albright with Bill Woodward. (Miramax,
$27.95.) A memoir by the former secretary of state and ambassador to the United
Nations.
PERSECUTION, by David Limbaugh. (Regnery, $27.95.) The author of "Absolute
Power" argues that "liberals are waging war against Christianity."
VISITS FROM THE AFTERLIFE, by Sylvia Browne with Lindsay Harrison. (Dutton,
$25.95.) A professed psychic describes "the truth about hauntings, spirits and
reunions with lost loved ones."
HEART FULL OF LIES, by Ann Rule. (Free Press, $26.) The story of Liysa
Northon, who in the fall of 2000 killed her husband while they were on a camping
trip in a remote part of Oregon.
LIVING HISTORY, by Hillary Rodham Clinton. (Simon & Schuster, $28.) A memoir
by the junior senator from New York and former first lady.
BENJAMIN FRANKLIN, by Walter Isaacson. (Simon & Schuster, $30.) A
biography of the scientist, inventor, writer and Revolutionary statesman.
SHUT UP & SING, by Laura Ingraham. (Regnery, $27.95.) The political
commentator attacks the "elites" of Hollywood, Washington and New York.
